title: Emotional mums who inspired organ donor campaign meet for first time 25 years on
text:

Two campaigning mums who inspired The Mirror’s organ donor campaign have met for the first time.

Rosemary Cox, 80, gave Emma Johnson an emotional embrace to say thank you for completing the job she started almost 30 years ago.

She worked tirelessly with late husband John and daughter Christine to set up the NHS Organ donor register in memory of son Peter.

He was just 24 when he died on November 11, 1989 from a brain tumour. Peter wanted to help as many people as he could through organ donation. His sacrifice saved or transformed the lives of 17 people.

The NHS Organ Donor Register was founded in 1994, a fitting legacy.

(Image: Andy Commins/Daily Mirror)

(Image: Philip Coburn/Daily Mirror)

This week, as the NHS marks the register’s 25th anniversary, it was revealed that it had saved or transformed 20,000 lives.

In 2017 Emma’s son Max received a heart from donor Keira Ball , nine, of Barnstaple, Devon, after more than six months on the waiting list.

“Without it, Max would not be here,” Emma told Rosemary. But the 11-year-old, poster boy of the Mirror’s Change the Law for Life crusade, has at least repaid some of that debt.

Over almost three decades, the Cox family campaigned for the new opt-out system in England, where everyone is understood to be a donor when they die. It starts next spring, named Max and Keira’s Law after our story touched the heart of then Prime Minister Theresa May .

(Image: Philip Coburn/Daily Mirror)

Peter died on Remembrance Sunday, a “special day” for his loved ones, as they remember the sacrifices he made as the nation remembers those who gave their lives in combat.

“It is the 30th anniversary of his death this year; it gives us such comfort to know that Peter’s life was not in vain,” explained Christine, 57, of London. “The register has helped to save thousands of people since it was set up in 1994.

“Max and Keira’s law is fantastic. We can take a step back now knowing we have seen what we set out to achieve.”

In Wales, where the system came in back in 2015, they now have the highest consent rate of all the UK nations at 77%, up from 58% .

Sheer persistence and campaigning by Peter’s family persuaded the Tories to introduce the donor register after Christine made a speech at the 1993 Tory conference.

By 2005, more than 12 million had signed up. That figure now stands at 25 million, 38% of the population.

“If you are prepared to receive an organ to save your life – you should be prepared to give,” says Rosemary, of Wolverhampton, West Midlands, who met Vera Davison, whose late husband Patrick received Peter’s heart, at the Pride of Britain awards in March.

Emma, 49, of Winsford, Cheshire, described their work as “amazing”, saying the Change the Law for Life campaign carried on the legacy of the donor register.

“Now we will have publicity for the new law, and that should lead to more donations,” she said.

Christine said: “Max has done so much, he is amazing. He has finished the work we have done. The Mirror’s support has been fabulous. They always backed our call for the register, and now for the new law.”

Anthony Clarkson, Director of Organ Donation and Transplantation for NHS Blood and Transplant, said: “This is an incredible legacy for Peter and we are grateful to the whole Cox family for their tireless work over the years.”

Visit www.organdonation.nhs.uk to find out further information
description: EXCLUSIVE: NHS Organ Donor Register was founded in 1994 after Rosemary Cox, of Wolverhampton, West Midlands, and Emma Johnson, from Winsford, Cheshire, led the Daily Mirror campaign Change the Law for Life
